p: PerMANOVA results indicated that species composition differed according to study year ( F 1,884 = 10.21, R 2 = 0.05; P = 0.01), deer reduction ( F 1,884 = 56.18, R 2 = 0.05; P = 0.01) and the interaction between year and deer reduction ( F 1,884=17.3, R 2=0.02; P=0.01). Study factors, although significant, explained a small percentage of the variation (indicated by R 2 values). NMDS ordination indicated a difference in vegetation composition before and after deer reduction ( Fig. 3). Both study year and deer reduction had a significant goodness of fit ( R 2=0.23, P < 0.001 and R 2=0.1, P < 0.001, respectively). Changes were driven by the six most abundant species: non-native A. petiolata and five native early-successional perennial forbs ( Circaea lutetiana, Geum canadense, Laportea canadense, Polygonum virginianum and Viola sororia). Collectively, these six species contributed over 50 % of total cover following deer reduction.
